references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.B05LAN01USGP: Lannoo, M. 2005. M. Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA (2005), p. 1094
references.A80HOF02NAUS: Hoffman, R. L. 1980. Pseudacris brachyphona. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 234.1-234.2.
references.B13GRE01USGP: Green, D.M., L.A. Weir, G.S. Casper, and M.J. Lannoo. 2013.  North American Amphibians: Distribution and Diversity.  University of California Press. Berkeley, California. 340 pp.
references.B75CON01NAUS: Conant, R. 1975. A Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern and Central North America. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xvii + 429 pp.
references.B87GRE01NAUS: Green, N. B., and T. K. Pauley. 1987. Amphibians and reptiles in West Virginia. University of Pittsburg Press, Pittsburg, Pennsylvania. xi + 241 pp.
references.W15NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2015. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B13DOD01USGP: Dodd, C.K. 2013. Frogs of the United States and Canada.  The Johns Hopkins University Press. 982 Pp.
references.B75MOU01NAUS: Mount, R. H. 1975. The Reptiles and Amphibians of Alabama. Auburn University Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn, Alabama. vii + 347 pp.
references.W04HAM06USGP: Hammerson, G. 2004. Pseudacris brachyphona. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2015.2. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 23 May 2015.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.B71BAR01NAUS: Barbour, R. W. 1971. Amphibians and reptiles of Kentucky. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 334 pp.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
references.A94COC01NAUS: Cocroft, R. B. 1994. A cladistic analysis of chorus frog phylogeny (Hylidae:PSEUDACRIS). Herpetologica 50:420-437.

habitat_description:
The range of the mountain chorus frog is comprised of disjunct populations from southwest Philadelphia and southeast Ohio, extends into north Tennessee. A separate population is distributed in north central Alabama, neighboring Tennessee and Mississippi, small patch in north Georgia and nearby south east Tennessee and southwest North Carolina (Conant and Collins 1998). Current distribution is much reduced from its historical records; now, its range is mainly the Appalachian Plateau Physiographic Province from central and western Pennsylvania to southwestern Georgia, central Alabama, and northeastern Mississippi (Hoffman 1980).

Habitats of preference are hilly areas of woodlands (Behler and King 1979). Other preferred habitats are forested slopes and hilltops of an elevation of at least 1100 meters. Found often far from bodies of water. Breeding takes place in shallow, small pools in woods or their edges. Also, associated with pools and ditches that form downflow of hillside springs (Conant and Collins 1998). Also, furrows of plowed fields, pools in roadruts, mountaintop bogs, seepages, temporary pools, and woodland springs. Breeding occurs in shallow water of wetlands found from 365-1341m (Lannoo 2005).

610m movement with season and 1219m movement between breeding seasons (Green 1952 in Lannoo 2005).
